articles.headline: The Trump Administration Could Test Whether Deficits Help the Economy
articles.snippet: Donald Trump appears likely to enact a fun-house mirror version of something many liberal economists have advocated for years.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump appears likely to enact a fun-house mirror version of something many liberal economists have advocated for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s a surprising conclusion you reach when you start to game out what economic policy will look like in Donald J. Trump’s administration: While many details of his policy agenda are likely to be staunchly opposed by the left, Mr. Trump appears likely to enact a fun-house mirror version of what many liberal economists have advocated for years: Keynesian fiscal stimulus.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Victory Is Met With Shock Across a Wide Political Divide
articles.snippet: Democrats were particularly crestfallen that Hillary Clinton had a slender lead in the popular vote but lost in the Electoral College, a fate similar to Al Gore’s in 2000.
articles.abstract: Democrats were particularly crestfallen that Hillary Clinton had a slender lead in the popular vote but lost in the Electoral College, a fate similar to Al Gore’s in 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American political establishment reeled on Wednesday as leaders in both parties began coming to grips with four years of President Donald J. Trump in the White House, a once-unimaginable scenario that has now plunged the United States and its allies and adversaries into a period of deep uncertainty about the policies and impact of his administration.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Expectations, and Her Ultimate Campaign Missteps
articles.snippet: On Wednesday, Democrats recognized two central problems of Mrs. Clinton’s candidacy: Her decades in Washington and her inability to tap into the anti-establishment and anti-Wall Street rage.
articles.abstract: On Wednesday, Democrats recognized two central problems of Mrs. Clinton’s candidacy: Her decades in Washington and her inability to tap into the anti-establishment and anti-Wall Street rage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, a prominent group of supporters asked Hillary Clinton to address a prestigious St. Patrick’s Day gathering at the University of Notre Dame, an invitation that previous presidential candidates had jumped on.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Reels After Trump’s Election
articles.snippet: For some, there was a realization that the tech industry’s relationship with government — and the public — is likely to shift in a fundamental way.
articles.abstract: For some, there was a realization that the tech industry’s relationship with government — and the public — is likely to shift in a fundamental way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s luminaries woke up Wednesday morning to a darkened new global order, one that the ceaseless optimism of their tech-powered visions seemed suddenly unable to conquer.

articles.headline: Trump Rides a Wave of Fury That May Damage Global Prosperity
articles.snippet: The election of Donald J. Trump joins Brexit as part of a middle-class and blue-collar insurrection against global free trade that could ultimately backfire.
articles.abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump joins Brexit as part of a middle-class and blue-collar insurrection against global free trade that could ultimately backfire.
articles.lead_paragraph: A populist insurrection is gaining force in much of the world, drawing middle-class and blue-collar recruits who lament that they have been left behind by globalization. This upheaval threatens to upend the economic order that has prevailed since the end of World War II.

articles.headline: Trump Expected to Seek Deep Cuts in Business Regulations
articles.snippet: The Trump administration is likely to seek vast cuts in regulations across the banking, health care and energy industries.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration is likely to seek vast cuts in regulations across the banking, health care and energy industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unwinding of Dodd-Frank. The firing up of shuttered coal plants. The rollback of rules that increase overtime pay for low-wage workers.

articles.headline: News Outlets Wonder Where the Predictions Went Wrong
articles.snippet: After projecting a relatively easy victory for Hillary Clinton with all the certainty of a calculus solution, major outlets scrambled to provide candid answers.
articles.abstract: After projecting a relatively easy victory for Hillary Clinton with all the certainty of a calculus solution, major outlets scrambled to provide candid answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The country’s major news organizations, as surprised as anybody by Donald J. Trump’s ascension to the presidency, faced a question from their audiences on Wednesday that was laced with a sense of betrayal and anger: How did you get it so wrong?

articles.headline: World Is About to Find Out What Donald Trump Really Believes
articles.snippet: Many of his closest supporters have long cautioned that his most headline-grabbing proposals should not be taken literally — they are guideposts, not plans.
articles.abstract: Many of his closest supporters have long cautioned that his most headline-grabbing proposals should not be taken literally — they are guideposts, not plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Donald J. Trump’s private conversations and public commentary, one guiding principle shines through: The world is a zero-sum place, and nations, like real estate developers, are either on the winning side of a deal or the losing side.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Maggie Haberman and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Victory Was Built on Unique Coalition of White Voters
articles.snippet: Millions of people who had once flocked to President Obama’s promise of hope and change saw in Mr. Trump their best chance to be heard and protected.
articles.abstract: Millions of people who had once flocked to President Obama’s promise of hope and change saw in Mr. Trump their best chance to be heard and protected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s America flowered through the old union strongholds of the Midwest, along rivers and rail lines that once moved coal from southern Ohio and the hollows of West Virginia to the smelters of Pennsylvania.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Nate Cohn

articles.headline: How Data Failed Us in Calling an Election
articles.snippet: Predictive analytics, and election forecasting in particular, remains a young science. Experts say some of the models could be off 15 to 20 percent.
articles.abstract: Predictive analytics, and election forecasting in particular, remains a young science. Experts say some of the models could be off 15 to 20 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a rough night for number crunchers. And for the faith that people in every field — business, politics, sports and academia — have increasingly placed in the power of data.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Where the U.S. Is a Rival, Trump Election Is Greeted With a Smile
articles.snippet: The election of Donald J. Trump presents an unexpected gift to leaders — political, spiritual and ideological — who resent the encroachment of the West.
articles.abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump presents an unexpected gift to leaders — political, spiritual and ideological — who resent the encroachment of the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOTOR, Montenegro — Just over an hour after Donald J. Trump secured his stunning triumph, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia congratulated the victor and looked forward to “constructive dialogue.” China’s president, Xi Jinping, waited a little longer, sending Mr. Trump a similarly measured message of hope and appealing for “cooperation for mutual gain.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Neil MacFarquhar and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Trump and Obama Hold Cordial 90-Minute Meeting in Oval Office
articles.snippet: President Obama met with President-elect Donald J. Trump, saying about the Trumps: “We want to make sure that they feel welcome.”
articles.abstract: President Obama met with President-elect Donald J. Trump, saying about the Trumps: “We want to make sure that they feel welcome.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, President Obama said that Donald J. Trump was unqualified, temperamentally unfit and a threat to the republic who should never be president.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Could Put Climate Change on Course for ‘Danger Zone’
articles.snippet: President-elect Trump has vowed to cancel the Paris climate accord, jeopardizing what scientists say is a critical 3.6-degree irreversible temperature target.
articles.abstract: President-elect Trump has vowed to cancel the Paris climate accord, jeopardizing what scientists say is a critical 3.6-degree irreversible temperature target.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a look at how sharply policy in Washington will change under the administration of Donald J. Trump, look no further than the environment.
